title: Army sniffer dog Vidar saved hundreds of lives, but had to retire because of his fear of loud noises
text:
Vidar and his owner Angie, an Army Reserve medic Vidar is an army sniffer dog who was posted to Afghanistan to search for bombs but retired after becoming scared of loud noises.
His tale has now been told in a short story to encourage people who struggle to read.
Watch the report below:
Play video Vidar is a Belgian Malinois - an energetic breed of dog often used for searches and security.
Nothing tires them out and they will just go and go and go, which is what makes them so perfect for the Army, and the high tempo work that we do there.
He's also got this amazing nose for explosives, and parts there of. That's what he was trained for in Afghanistan.
– Angie McDonnell, Army Reserve medic Vidar served on the front line for two years. But the conditions took their toll.
He developed a phobia of loud noises - the result of hearing explosions during his service.
Vidar in Afghanistan What started happening was he started reacting to the bangs, so any gunshots, explosions.
He started getting very nervous, his tail would go between his legs, he started licking his lips. He didn't want to search.
– Angie McDonnell Vidar and Angie's story now been turned into a book - one designed to encourage more people to read.
Vidar's not sure what to make of his new book... Angie says despite his condition, the work dogs like Vidar do is invaluable.
To work them in a theatre that saves lives - and they do save countless lives - not only soldiers, but also civilians in the countries they work in - I think it's an amazing job!
They get rewarded with their ball and lots of cuddles at the end of the day
– Angie McDonnell With Vidar's condition, and his eyesight failing, Angie was able to do adopt him in 2014.
Vidar's army days might be behind him, but he's forged a friendship that'll last for much longer.
